The Michigan Health & Hospital Association (MHA) recently announced that McLaren Port Huron was a recipient of its annual Ludwig Community Benefit Award. The award is presented to member organizations involved in collaborative programs to improve the health and well-being of area residents. McLaren Port Huron was recognized for partnering with the Port Huron Area School District (PHASD) to form the Biomedical Science Partnership, reinforcing the importance of healthy lifestyles and strengthening the potential for high school students to choose health care careers. McLaren Port Huron received $5,000 from the MHA Health Foundation to assist in its health improvement efforts. The funds will be earmarked for PHASD’s biomedical program. Port Huron Schools has been proud to be part of a statewide Equity Pilot through a partnership with the Michigan MTSS Technical Assistance Center and the
Michigan Department of Education for the past four years. PHS - Central Middle School, PHS - Holland Woods Middle School and PHS - Port Huron High School have participated in focused staff professional development and data review in order to reduce racial discipline disparities by creating equitable environments and increasing staff self awareness. Some of the professional development topics include understanding institutional racism, identity awareness, impact of power and privilege, implicit bias, and culturally responsive practices. The district is looking forward to expanding this work to all schools.

Port Huron Schools is also continuing the close examination of curriculum and instructional materials to ensure diversity and the honoring of different races and cultures. It is important that our students engage in a curriculum that is reflective of both their life experiences and those of others.

text:
Port Huron Schools has been proud to be part of a statewide Equity Pilot through a partnership with the Michigan MTSS Technical Assistance Center and the
Michigan Department of Education for the past four years. PHS - Central Middle School, PHS - Holland Woods Middle School and PHS - Port Huron High School have participated in focused staff professional development and data review in order to reduce racial discipline disparities by creating equitable environments and increasing staff self awareness. Some of the professional development topics include understanding institutional racism, identity awareness, impact of power and privilege, implicit bias, and culturally responsive practices. The district is looking forward to expanding this work to all schools.

During these days of quarantine and working on school work from home, PHS - Garfield Elementary School Student Council President Elena Glenn has been thinking about how to help others. She asked Mrs. Norah Gaglio, Intervention Specialist/Math teacher and Student Council Advisor at Garfield, if funds raised during a February fundraiser could be spent helping essential workers. Mrs. Gaglio met via Zoom with Student Council members last week to discuss this. The students gathered ideas and voted to help their community during this unprecedented time by donating:

$200 to feed frontline workers at McLaren Port Huron
$100 to buy prepackaged snacks for the staff at Sanborn Gratiot Memorial Home

Garfield’s first grade students have worked with the residents of Sanborn for the last few years, and this tradition has continued. Students were invited, via classroom teachers and daily announcements, to make cards for residents and leave them in an envelope at Garfield’s front entry.

PROTECTION GEAR DONATIONS NEEDED

PHS and St Clair County Office of Homeland Security need your help. Care facilities in our area are facing potential shortages of essential medical supplies and personal protective equipment. Gov. Whitmer has called upon citizens and businesses to donate items needed most by hospitals and medical providers. Because of this, Port Huron Schools have opened the front lobbies of both high schools for anyone to drop off NEW items (still in package) to donate. Items requested at this time are (new still in package only please):

N95 Masks
Disposable Medical Coveralls / Gowns
Disposable Gloves
Face Shields
Masks (either hand sewn, or manufactured)
Safety Glasses / Goggles
Hand Sanitizer
Wipes
No-Touch Thermometers

Please do not include donations of “personal items” such as clothing or other personal care items. We are not able to use or disperse those items at this time.

THANK YOU !

Look for the Meet Up and Eat Up signs to direct them to where the meals will be served.
The high school sites will also have outdoor wifi available for students without access to download their academic needs while our doors are closed.

post_text: Our students at Central MS and Port Huron High School had an incredible opportunity today. Erik Denson and Jay Haigler both Chief Engineers at NASA and Dr. Ayana Flewellen a Professor from Berkeley CA specializing in Terrestrial Archeology, spoke to our students about a project they are working on and careers in diving, archeology and our space program. Our students were amazed to learn that 75 years ago, Lt. Frank Moody’s (a Tuskegee Airman) plane crashed in Lake Huron near Port Huron. The presenters’ organization (Diving With a Purpose) is working with our city to build a memorial to heroes like Lt. Moody near the Blue Water Bridge. Even our own Dave Koester (PHS Director of Operations) and Anita Ashford (Port Huron City Council) were in on the fun. The adults in the audience were so proud of how respectful our students were to our guests and know they learned a lot. #1PHASD Diving With A Purpose Society of Black Archaeologists NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration

St. Clair County RESA
January 15 at 4:01 PM ·

Maria Cavis, an elementary Special Education teacher at Keewahdin Elementary in Port Huron, has been recognized as St. Clair County’s Distinguished Teacher for December 2019. Cavis was presented with the award during a surprise classroom visit on Jan. 15.

The Distinguished Teacher award, sponsored by RESA, is given monthly during the school year to educators who exemplify high teaching standards.

Catherine Woolman and Charles Lesser nominated Cavis for the honor. Brenda Tenniswood, RESA director of Education Services said of Cavis, “She creates individual support plans based on each student's needs and has created school-to-home connections with parents to ensure parents have a voice in their student's education and that they are well informed of their student's progress.”

Cavis also received $350 for her classroom from Insurance Specialists Agency of Marysville, the local MEEMIC agent.

post_text: Last night, our #1PHASD Community Relations/Marketing Director Keely Baribeau was honored to be named the 2019 recipient of the "Gerri Allen Outstanding School Communicator Award" by her colleagues in the Michigan School Public Relations Association (MSPRA).
